docs.title: What is CCG?
docs.text: Conventional Commits Generator (CCG) is a powerful command-line interface tool that helps developers create standardized git commit messages following the Conventional Commits specification. Say goodbye to inconsistent commit messages and embrace a professional, standardized workflow.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Interactive Interface - Beautiful, user-friendly prompts guide you through creating perfect commit messages every time

  • Emoji Support - Optional GitHub-compatible emoji codes make your commits visually expressive and easy to scan

  • Advanced Git Operations - Edit, delete, and manage commits with intelligent history rewriting and safety checks

  • Tag Management - Create and push semantic version tags with annotated messages

  • Flexible Workflows - Work with specific paths, multiple repositories, and various git workflows seamlessly

  • Pre-commit Integration - Automatic detection and execution of pre-commit hooks for code quality assurance

docs.title: Why Use CCG?
docs.text:
Benefits

  • Consistency: Standardized commits across your team
  • Clarity: Clear commit messages make code review easier
  • Safety: Built-in validation and confirmation prompts

Perfect For

  • Open source projects
  • Team collaborations
  • Professional development workflows
  • Projects using semantic versioning
  • Automated release processes

docs.title: Enforcement Responsibilities
docs.text:
Community leaders are responsible for clarifying and enforcing our standards of acceptable behavior and will take appropriate and fair corrective action in response to any behavior that they deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, or harmful.

Community leaders have the right and responsibility to remove, edit, or reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, and other contributions that are not aligned to this Code of Conduct, and will communicate reasons for moderation decisions when appropriate.

docs.title: Scope
docs.text: This Code of Conduct applies within all community spaces, and also applies when an individual is officially representing the community in public spaces. Examples of representing our community include using an official email address, posting via an official social media account, or acting as an appointed representative at an online or offline event.

docs.title: Enforcement
docs.text:
Instances of abusive, harassing, or otherwise unacceptable behavior may be reported to the community leaders responsible for enforcement at egydiobolonhezi@gmail.com.

All community leaders are obligated to respect the privacy and security of the reporter of any incident.

docs.title: Enforcement Guidelines
docs.text: Community leaders will follow these Community Impact Guidelines in determining the consequences for any action they deem in violation of this Code of Conduct:

docs.title: 1. Correction

Community Impact: Use of inappropriate language or other behavior deemed unprofessional or unwelcome in the community.

Consequence: A private, written warning from community leaders, providing clarity around the nature of the violation and an explanation of why the behavior was inappropriate. A public apology may be requested.

docs.title: 2. Warning
docs.text:

Consequence: A warning with consequences for continued behavior. No interaction with the people involved, including unsolicited interaction with those enforcing the Code of Conduct, for a specified period of time. This includes avoiding interactions in community spaces as well as external channels like social media. Violating these terms may lead to a temporary or permanent ban.

Consequence: A temporary ban from any sort of interaction or public communication with the community for a specified period of time. No public or private interaction with the people involved, including unsolicited interaction with those enforcing the Code of Conduct, is allowed during this period. docs.title: 4. Permanent Ban

docs.title: Contributing Guide
docs.text: Thank you for your interest in contributing to CCG! This guide will help you get started.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Fork and clone the repository
  2. Set up environment: ./scripts/setup_venv.sh
  3. Install pre-commit: pre-commit install
  4. Create branch: git checkout -b feat/my-feature
  5. Make changes and add tests
  6. Test across versions: ./scripts/tox-mise.sh
  7. Commit and Push with CCG: ccg

docs.title: Automated Setup (Recommended)
docs.text:
# Clone your fork
git clone https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/conventional-commits-generator.git
cd conventional-commits-generator

# Run automated setup
./scripts/setup_venv.sh

# Activate environment
source .venv/bin/activate

docs.title: Install Pre-commit Hooks
docs.text:
Pre-commit hooks ensure code quality before commits:

# Install hooks
pre-commit install

# Test hooks
pre-commit run --all-files

The hooks will check for:

  • Trailing whitespace
  • File endings
  • TOML/YAML syntax
  • Debug statements
  • Large files

docs.title: 1. Make Changes
docs.text:
# Create feature branch
git checkout -b feat/new-feature

# Edit code
vim src/ccg/module.py

# Add tests
vim tests/unit/test_module.py

docs.title: 2. Run Tests
docs.text:
# Quick test with current Python version
pytest

# Test across all supported versions (3.9-3.13)
./scripts/tox-mise.sh

# Test specific version
./scripts/tox-mise.sh -e py312

# Test in parallel (faster)
./scripts/tox-mise.sh -p auto

docs.title: 3. Create Commit
docs.text:
Use CCG to create conventional commits:

# Commit and Push with CCG
ccg

# Follow the interactive prompts

docs.title: 4. Submit PR
docs.text:
# Create PR on GitHub
# Use conventional commit format in PR title
# Example: "feat(cli): add verbose output flag"

docs.title: Style Guidelines
docs.text:
• Type Hints: Required for all functions
  • Docstrings: Google Style for public functions
  • Line Length: Maximum 100 characters
  • Formatting: Use f-strings for string formatting
  • Coverage: 100% test coverage required

docs.title: Docstring Example
docs.text:
def validate_commit_message(message: str) -> tuple[bool, str]:
    """Validate a commit message against Conventional Commits specification.

    Args:
        message: The commit message to validate.

    Returns:
        A tuple containing validation status and error message:
        - bool: True if valid, False otherwise
        - str: Error message if invalid, empty string if valid

    Examples:
        >>> validate_commit_message("feat: add feature")
        (True, "")
        >>> validate_commit_message("invalid")
        (False, "Invalid format")
    """
    # Implementation...

Learn more: Google Python Style Guide - Docstrings

docs.title: Coverage
docs.text:
All code must maintain 100% test coverage:

# Run tests with coverage
pytest

# View coverage report
pytest --cov-report=html

docs.title: Multi-version Testing
docs.text:
Test across all supported Python versions:

# Test all versions
./scripts/tox-mise.sh

# The script handles:
# - mise installation (if needed)
# - tox installation (if needed)
# - Python 3.9-3.13 installation (if needed)
# - Running tests across all versions

docs.title: Type Checking
docs.text:
# Run mypy type checker
mypy src/ccg

# Or via tox
./scripts/tox-mise.sh -e mypy

docs.title: Before Submitting
docs.text:
1. Run full test suite:
./scripts/tox-mise.sh
pre-commit run --all-files
mypy src/ccg

  1. Update documentation if needed

  2. Ensure 100% coverage maintained

Checklist:

docs.title: Commit Types
docs.text: CCG supports all standard conventional commit types with clear descriptions and optional emoji support.

docs.title: Available Types
docs.text: Type Description Emoji feat A new feature ✨ fix A bug fix 🐛 docs Documentation changes 📚 style Code style/formatting changes 💄 refactor Code refactoring 🔨 test Adding or modifying tests 🧪 chore Maintenance tasks 🔧 perf Performance improvements ⚡ ci CI/CD changes 👷 build Build system changes 📦 revert Reverts a previous commit ⏪

docs.title: feat - New Features
docs.text:
Use feat when you add a new feature or capability to the codebase.

Examples:

feat: add user authentication
feat(api): implement OAuth2 login
feat!: redesign navigation system (breaking change)

docs.title: fix - Bug Fixes
docs.text:
Use fix when you repair a bug or issue in the code.

Examples:

fix: resolve memory leak in data processing
fix(ui): correct button alignment on mobile
fix: handle null pointer exception in validator

docs.title: docs - Documentation
docs.text:
Use docs for documentation-only changes (no code changes).

Examples:

docs: update installation instructions
docs(api): add examples to README
docs: fix typos in contributing guide

docs.title: style - Code Style
docs.text:
Use style for formatting changes that don't affect code behavior (whitespace, semicolons, etc.).

Examples:

style: format code with black
style: fix indentation in utils module
style: remove trailing whitespace

docs.title: refactor - Code Refactoring
docs.text:
Use refactor when you restructure code without changing its external behavior.

Examples:

refactor: extract validation logic to separate class
refactor(db): optimize query performance
refactor: simplify error handling

docs.title: test - Tests
docs.text:
Use test when adding, modifying, or fixing tests.

Examples:

test: add unit tests for authentication
test(api): increase coverage to 100%
test: fix flaky integration test

docs.title: chore - Maintenance
docs.text:
Use chore for maintenance tasks, dependency updates, and other housekeeping.

Examples:

chore: update dependencies
chore: bump version to 2.3.0
chore(deps): upgrade pytest to 7.4.0

docs.title: perf - Performance
docs.text:
Use perf for performance improvements.

Examples:

perf: optimize database queries
perf(cache): implement Redis caching
perf: reduce bundle size by 30%

docs.title: ci - Continuous Integration
docs.text:
Use ci for CI/CD configuration and pipeline changes.

Examples:

ci: add GitHub Actions workflow
ci: update test matrix to include Python 3.13
ci: configure automated releases

docs.title: build - Build System
docs.text:
Use build for changes to build configuration and scripts.

Examples:

build: update webpack configuration
build: add production build script
build(docker): optimize image size

docs.title: revert - Revert Changes
docs.text:
Use revert when reverting a previous commit.

Examples:

revert: revert "feat: add new API endpoint"
revert: undo breaking changes from #123

docs.title: Breaking Changes
docs.text:
Add ! after the type or BREAKING CHANGE: in the footer to indicate breaking changes:

feat!: remove deprecated API endpoints

BREAKING CHANGE: The old /api/v1 endpoints have been removed.
Use /api/v2 instead.

docs.title: Scopes
docs.text:
Add an optional scope to provide additional context:

feat(auth): add two-factor authentication
fix(ui): resolve navigation menu overflow
docs(api): update endpoint documentation

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before installing CCG, make sure you have Python 3.9 or higher installed.

Installing pip or pipx

pipx (Recommended)pip

pipx installs Python CLI tools in isolated environments. Install it with:

# On Ubuntu/Debian
sudo apt install pipx
pipx ensurepath

# On macOS
brew install pipx
pipx ensurepath

# On Windows
python -m pip install --user pipx
python -m pipx ensurepath

# Using pip (any OS)
python -m pip install --user pipx
python -m pipx ensurepath

After installation, restart your terminal.

pip comes pre-installed with Python. Verify it's available:

pip --version
# or
python -m pip --version

If pip is not installed, follow the official pip installation guide.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
pipx (Recommended)pip 
pipx install conventional-commits-generator

pip install conventional-commits-generator

docs.title: Test CCG command
docs.text:
# Run CCG
ccg --version

That's it! CCG will guide you through an interactive prompt to create a perfect conventional commit.

docs.title: Frequently Asked Questions
docs.text: Common questions and troubleshooting for CCG users.

docs.title: What is Conventional Commits?
docs.text:
Conventional Commits is a specification for adding human and machine-readable meaning to commit messages. It provides a lightweight convention for commit history that makes it easier to write automated tools.

Learn more at conventionalcommits.org.

docs.title: Why should I use CCG?
docs.text:
Benefits:

  • Consistency: Standardized commits across your team
  • Clarity: Clear commit messages make code review easier
  • Safety: Built-in validation and confirmation prompts

docs.title: Does CCG work with GitHub/GitLab/Bitbucket?
docs.text: Yes! CCG is a git tool that works with any git hosting platform including GitHub, GitLab, Bitbucket, Azure DevOps, and self-hosted git servers.

docs.title: Can I use CCG without pipx?
docs.text:
Yes, you can install with pip:

pip install conventional-commits-generator

However, pipx is recommended to avoid dependency conflicts.

docs.title: How do I update CCG?
docs.text:
pipx 
pipx upgrade conventional-commits-generator
pip 
pip install --upgrade conventional-commits-generator

docs.title: Does CCG require specific Python version?
docs.text:
CCG requires Python 3.9 or higher. Check your version:

python3 --version

docs.title: Can I use CCG without push access?
docs.text: Yes! You can use CCG to create commits locally. When asked to push, simply answer "no".

docs.title: How do I skip the body?
docs.text: Just press CTRL + D when prompted for the commit body. The body is optional.

docs.title: Can I edit a commit I already pushed?
docs.text:
Yes, use ccg --edit. However, this requires force pushing and can affect collaborators.

Warning

Editing pushed commits rewrites history. Coordinate with your team.

docs.title: Can I delete multiple commits at once?
docs.text: No, CCG deletes one commit at a time for safety. Run ccg --delete multiple times if needed.

docs.title: Does CCG support merge commits?
docs.text:
CCG focuses on regular commits. For merges, use standard git commands:

git merge feature-branch
# or
git merge --no-ff feature-branch

docs.title: "Command not found: ccg"
docs.text:
Cause: CCG is not in your PATH.

Solutions:

  1. Ensure pipx path is configured:
pipx ensurepath
source ~/.bashrc  # or ~/.zshrc
  1. Check installation:
pipx list  # Should show conventional-commits-generator
  1. Reinstall:
pipx install --force conventional-commits-generator

docs.title: "Not a git repository"
docs.text:
Cause: Current directory is not a git repository.

Solution:

# Initialize git
git init

# Or navigate to a git repository
cd /path/to/your/repo

docs.title: "No remote repository configured"
docs.text:
Cause: Git repository has no remote.

Solution:

git remote add origin <repository-url>

docs.title: "Permission denied" when pushing
docs.text:
Cause: Authentication or permission issues.

Solutions:

  1. Check repository URL:
git remote -v
  1. Test SSH access (for SSH URLs):
ssh -T git@github.com

  1. Verify permissions: Ensure you have write access to the repository.

  2. Update credentials: Reconfigure git credentials.

docs.title: "Pre-commit checks failed"
docs.text:
Cause: Pre-commit hooks detected issues.

Solution:

  1. Review failed checks:
pre-commit run --all-files

  1. Fix reported issues

  2. Run CCG again:

ccg

docs.title: Input/Output encoding errors
docs.text:
Cause: Terminal encoding issues (rare).

Solution:

export PYTHONIOENCODING=utf-8
ccg

docs.title: Can I customize commit types?
docs.text: Currently, CCG uses standard conventional commit types. Custom types are not supported but may be added in future versions.

docs.title: Does CCG support co-authors?
docs.text:
Yes! Add co-authors in the commit body:

Co-authored-by: Name <email@example.com>
Co-authored-by: Another Name <another@example.com>

CCG automatically adds itself as a co-author.

docs.title: Can I disable emoji?
docs.text: Yes, answer "no" when prompted "Include emoji in commit message?".

docs.title: Does CCG work offline?
docs.text: Yes, for local operations (commit, edit, delete). Push operations require internet connectivity.

docs.title: Can I use CCG in scripts?
docs.text:
CCG is interactive by design. For scripted commits, use standard git:

git commit -m "feat: automated commit"

docs.title: Works with pre-commit?
docs.text: Yes! CCG automatically detects and runs pre-commit hooks if .pre-commit-config.yaml exists.

docs.title: IDE/Editor Integration
docs.text:
CCG is a CLI tool. Run it in your IDE's integrated terminal:

  • VS Code: Terminal panel (Ctrl+`)
  • PyCharm: Terminal tool window
  • Vim/Neovim: :terminal command
  • Emacs: M-x shell

docs.title: How many commits can CCG show?
docs.text: By default, CCG shows recent commits. When editing/deleting, you choose how many to display (or "all").

docs.title: Is there a message length limit?
docs.text:
Yes, for user experience:

  • Type: 8 characters
  • Scope: 16 characters
  • Message: 64 characters
  • Body: 512 characters
  • Tag: 32 characters

These are soft limits enforced by the input validator.

docs.title: "Failed to get remote name"
docs.text:
Cause: No git remote configured.

Solution:

git remote add origin <url>

docs.title: "Commit validation failed"
docs.text:
Cause: Message doesn't follow conventional commit format.

Solution: Ensure format is: type(scope): description

Valid examples:

feat: add feature
fix(auth): resolve bug
docs(api)!: breaking docs change

docs.title: "Filter-branch failed"
docs.text:
Cause: Git operation failed during history rewriting.

Solution:

  1. Check for conflicting git operations
  2. Ensure clean working directory
  3. Try again or use manual git commands

docs.title: Should I always include emoji?
docs.text:
Personal preference. Emoji provides visual cues but isn't required by the specification.

Pros:

  • Easy to scan commit history
  • Color-coded by type
  • GitHub renders them nicely

Cons:

  • Some tools don't render emoji
  • Not part of official spec
  • Slightly longer messages

docs.title: How detailed should commit bodies be?
docs.text:
Include enough context for future developers (including yourself) to understand:

  • What changed (briefly, details in code)
  • Why it changed (motivation)
  • How it affects users (if applicable)
  • References to issues/docs

docs.title: Should I edit commits before PR?
docs.text:
Yes, if commits are:

  • Poorly worded
  • Missing important context
  • Not following conventions
  • WIP or debug commits

No, if:

  • Commits are clear and follow conventions
  • They accurately represent development history

docs.title: Where can I report bugs?
docs.text: Report bugs on GitHub: issues

docs.title: How do I request features?
docs.text:
Create a feature request issue on GitHub with:

  • Clear description
  • Use cases
  • Examples

  • Security: Security policy
  • Contributing: Contribution guidelines

python --version

If you don't have Python 3.9+, download it from python.org.

docs.title: Method 1: pipx (Recommended)
docs.text:
Why pipx?

pipx installs Python CLI applications in isolated environments, preventing dependency conflicts and making it easy to manage and update tools.

docs.title: Install pipx
docs.text:
LinuxmacOSWindows 
python3 -m pip install --user pipx
python3 -m pipx ensurepath

brew install pipx
pipx ensurepath

python -m pip install --user pipx
python -m pipx ensurepath

docs.title: Install CCG with pipx
docs.text: pipx install conventional-commits-generator

docs.title: Verify Installation
docs.text: ccg --version

docs.title: Method 2: pip
docs.text:
Global Installation

Installing with pip globally may cause dependency conflicts with other Python packages. Consider using a virtual environment or pipx instead.

pip install conventional-commits-generator

docs.title: Using a Virtual Environment (Recommended)
docs.text:
# Create virtual environment
python3 -m venv ccg-env

# Activate virtual environment
source ccg-env/bin/activate

# Install CCG
pip install conventional-commits-generator

# Verify installation
ccg --version

docs.title: Manual Setup (Alternative)
docs.text:
# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/EgydioBNeto/conventional-commits-generator.git
cd conventional-commits-generator

# Create virtual environment
python3 -m venv .venv

# Activate virtual environment
source .venv/bin/activate

# Install in development mode
pip install -e .

# Install with all dependencies (dev + test + docs)
pip install -e ".[dev,test,docs]"

docs.title: Verifying Installation
docs.text:
After installation, verify that CCG is working correctly:

# Check version
ccg --version

# Display help
ccg --help

# Test in a git repository
cd /path/to/your/git/repo
ccg --commit

You should see the CCG ASCII logo and interactive prompts.

docs.title: pipx
docs.text: pipx upgrade conventional-commits-generator

docs.title: pip
docs.text: pip install --upgrade conventional-commits-generator

docs.title: pipx
docs.text: pipx uninstall conventional-commits-generator

docs.title: pip
docs.text: pip uninstall conventional-commits-generator

docs.title: Command not found: ccg
docs.text:
Problem: After installation, running ccg shows "command not found"

Solutions:

  1. Check if the installation directory is in your PATH:
# For pipx
pipx ensurepath

# For pip (user install)
export PATH="$HOME/.local/bin:$PATH"  # Add to ~/.bashrc or ~/.zshrc
  1. Try running with python -m:
python -m ccg.cli
  1. Reinstall with correct method:
pipx install conventional-commits-generator

docs.title: Permission Denied
docs.text:
Problem: Installation fails with permission errors

Solutions:

  1. Use user installation (recommended):
pip install --user conventional-commits-generator
  1. Use pipx (recommended):
pipx install conventional-commits-generator
  1. Avoid sudo pip (not recommended):

Using sudo pip can break your system Python packages.

docs.title: Dependency Conflicts
docs.text:
Problem: Conflicts with prompt_toolkit or other dependencies

Solutions:

  1. Use pipx (installs in isolated environment):
pipx install conventional-commits-generator
  1. Use virtual environment:
python3 -m venv ccg-env
source ccg-env/bin/activate
pip install conventional-commits-generator

docs.title: Python Version Mismatch
docs.text:
Problem: Your Python version is below 3.9

Solutions:

  1. Install Python 3.9+ from python.org

  2. Use version managers:

misepyenv 
mise install python@3.12
mise global python@3.12

pyenv install 3.12
pyenv global 3.12

docs.title: Import Errors
docs.text:
Problem: ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'ccg'

Solutions:

  1. Ensure installation completed:

  2. Check if you're in the correct virtual environment:

which python
which ccg
  1. Reinstall:
pip uninstall conventional-commits-generator
pipx install conventional-commits-generator

docs.title: Quick Start Guide
docs.text: Get up and running with Conventional Commits Generator in minutes!

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Make sure you have:

  • Installed CCG
  • A Git repository to work with
  • Some uncommitted changes ready to commit

docs.title: Your First Commit
docs.text: Let's create your first conventional commit step by step.

docs.title: 1. Navigate to Your Repository
docs.text: cd /path/to/your/git/repository

docs.title: 2. Make Some Changes
docs.text:
# Example: modify a file
echo "# New feature" >> README.md

docs.title: 3. Run CCG
docs.text:
ccg

You'll see the CCG logo and repository information:

 ________      ________      ________
|\   ____\    |\   ____\    |\   ____\
\ \  \___|    \ \  \___|    \ \  \___|
 \ \  \        \ \  \        \ \  \  ___
  \ \  \____    \ \  \____    \ \  \|\  \
   \ \_______\   \ \_______\   \ \_______\
    \|_______|    \|_______|    \|_______|

 Conventional Commits Generator

Repository: my-project  Branch: main

docs.title: Interactive Prompts
docs.text: CCG will guide you through a series of prompts:

docs.title: Step 1: Choose Commit Type
docs.text:
┌──────────────────────┐
│ Commit Types         │
└──────────────────────┘

1. ✨ feat     - A new feature
2. 🐛 fix      - A bug fix
3. 🔧 chore    - Maintenance tasks
4. 🔨 refactor - Code refactoring
5. 💄 style    - Style changes
6. 📚 docs     - Documentation
7. 🧪 test     - Adding or modifying tests
8. 📦 build    - Build system changes
9. ⏪ revert   - Reverts a previous commit
10. 👷 ci      - CI/CD changes
11. ⚡ perf    - Performance improvements

Choose the commit type (number or name):

Pro Tip

You can type the number (e.g., 1) or the name (e.g., feat)

Example: Let's choose 1 for a new feature.

docs.title: Step 2: Enter Scope (Optional)
docs.text:
┌──────────────────────┐
│ Scope                │
└──────────────────────┘
ℹ The scope provides context for the commit (e.g., module or file name)
ℹ Examples: auth, ui, api, database

Enter the scope (optional, press Enter to skip):

Example: Let's type docs to indicate this change affects documentation.

docs.title: Step 3: Breaking Change
docs.text:
┌──────────────────────┐
│ Breaking Change      │
└──────────────────────┘
ℹ A breaking change means this commit includes incompatible changes
ℹ Examples: changing function signatures, removing features, etc.

Is this a BREAKING CHANGE? (y/n):

Example: Let's type n since this is not a breaking change.

docs.title: Step 4: Include Emoji
docs.text:
┌──────────────────────┐
│ Emoji                │
└──────────────────────┘
ℹ GitHub-compatible emojis can make your commits more visual and expressive
ℹ Examples: :sparkles: feat, :bug: fix, :books: docs

Include emoji in commit message? (y/n):

Example: Let's type y to include emojis.

docs.title: Step 5: Commit Message
docs.text:
┌──────────────────────┐
│ Commit Message       │
└──────────────────────┘
ℹ Provide a clear, concise description of the change
ℹ Examples: 'implement OAuth login', 'fix navigation bug', 'update documentation'

Enter the commit message:

Example: Let's type add installation guide.

docs.title: Step 6: Commit Body (Optional)
docs.text:
┌──────────────────────┐
│ Commit Body          │
└──────────────────────┘
ℹ Add implementation details, breaking changes, or issue references (optional)
ℹ Examples: 'Added Google OAuth integration', 'BREAKING: API endpoint changed', 'Fixes #123'

Commit body (optional):

Example: Let's add more details:

Detailed installation instructions for pipx, pip, and development setup.
Includes troubleshooting section.

Multiline Input

For commit body, you can:

  • With prompt_toolkit: Press Enter for new lines, Ctrl+D to finish
  • Without prompt_toolkit: Press Enter twice (empty line) to finish

docs.title: Step 7: Review
docs.text:
┌──────────────────────┐
│ Review               │
└──────────────────────┘
Commit: 📚 docs(docs): add installation guide

Body:
Detailed installation instructions for pipx, pip, and development setup.
Includes troubleshooting section.

Confirm this commit message? (Y/n):

Example: Type y to confirm.

docs.title: Step 8: Push Changes
docs.text:
✅ Commit message confirmed!

┌──────────────────────┐
│ Git Staging          │
└──────────────────────┘
→ Staging changes for .
✅ Changes staged successfully

┌──────────────────────┐
│ Commit               │
└──────────────────────┘
→ Committing changes...
✅ New commit successfully created!

┌──────────────────────┐
│ Push Changes         │
└──────────────────────┘
ℹ This will execute 'git push' command

Do you want to push these changes? (Y/n):

Example: Type y to push to remote, or n to keep changes local.

docs.title: Understanding the Result
docs.text:
After completion, your commit is created following the Conventional Commits specification:

:books: docs(docs): add installation guide

Detailed installation instructions for pipx, pip, and development setup.
Includes troubleshooting section.

Co-Authored-By: Agent <noreply@agent.com>

docs.title: Commit Format Breakdown
docs.text:
<emoji> <type>(<scope>): <description>

<body>

<footer>
  • Emoji (optional): Visual indicator (:books: → 📚)
  • Type: Category of change (docs)
  • Scope (optional): Area affected (docs)
  • Description: Brief summary (add installation guide)
  • Body (optional): Detailed explanation
  • Footer (optional): Breaking changes, issues, co-authors

docs.title: Quick Commit (No Body)
docs.text:
For simple changes, skip the body:

ccg
# Choose type: 2 (fix)
# Scope: [press Enter to skip]
# Breaking change: n
# Include emoji: y
# Message: resolve login redirect issue
# Body: [press Enter to skip]
# Confirm: y
# Push: y

Result: :bug: fix: resolve login redirect issue

docs.title: Feature with Breaking Change
docs.text:
For major changes:

ccg
# Choose type: 1 (feat)
# Scope: api
# Breaking change: y  ← Important!
# Include emoji: y
# Message: redesign authentication flow
# Body: BREAKING: Changed /auth endpoint to use JWT tokens
# Confirm: y
# Push: y

Result: :sparkles: feat(api)!: redesign authentication flow

docs.title: Important Notes
docs.text:
Git Repository Required

CCG must be run inside a Git repository. If you see "Not a git repository" error, run git init first.

Pre-commit Hooks

If your repository has .pre-commit-config.yaml, CCG will automatically:

  • Install pre-commit hooks
  • Run hooks on staged files
  • Abort commit if hooks fail

Remote Access

CCG checks remote repository access before operations. Ensure you have:

  • Configured remote (git remote add origin <url>)
  • Proper authentication (SSH keys or HTTPS credentials)
  • Push permissions

docs.title: No Changes to Commit
docs.text:
Problem: "No changes to commit" error

Solution: Make sure you have uncommitted changes:

git status  # Check for modified files

docs.title: Permission Denied
docs.text:
Problem: Can't push to remote

Solution: Check your git credentials:

git remote -v  # Verify remote URL
ssh -T git@github.com  # Test SSH (for SSH URLs)

docs.title: Pre-commit Hooks Failed
docs.text:
Problem: Commit aborted due to hook failures

Solution: Fix the issues reported by pre-commit:

pre-commit run --all-files  # See what's failing
# Fix the issues, then run ccg again

docs.title: Congratulations!
docs.text:
You've successfully created your first conventional commit with CCG!

Continue exploring the documentation to become a conventional commits expert.

docs.title: Usage Guide
docs.text: Comprehensive guide to all Conventional Commits Generator commands and features.

docs.title: Interactive Commit
docs.text:
The most common way to use CCG is the interactive mode:

ccg

This starts the interactive prompt that guides you through creating a conventional commit.

docs.title: Command-Line Flags
docs.text: CCG supports various flags to customize its behavior:

docs.title: --commit: Generate Message Only
docs.text:
Generate a commit message without actually creating a commit:

ccg --commit

Use Cases:

  • Preview commit message format
  • Test your commit message before committing
  • Generate messages for documentation or examples

docs.title: --push: Push Without Committing
docs.text:
Push existing commits to remote without creating a new commit:

ccg --push

Use Cases:

  • Push commits you've already created
  • Retry a failed push
  • Push to a new branch that doesn't exist remotely

Features:

  • Automatically detects if branch exists on remote
  • Offers to create remote branch with --set-upstream if needed
  • Checks remote access before pushing

docs.title: --edit: Edit Existing Commits
docs.text:
Edit commit messages of existing commits:

ccg --edit

Features:

  • Select from recent commits or enter commit hash
  • Validates new message against conventional commits format
  • Uses git commit --amend for latest commit (fast)
  • Uses git filter-branch for older commits (rewrites history)
  • Offers force push for commits already on remote

Workflow:

  1. Choose how many recent commits to display
  2. Select commit by number or hash
  3. View current commit details
  4. Enter new commit message and body
  5. Review changes
  6. Confirm edit
  7. Optionally push with force flag

Warning: History Rewriting

Editing commits rewrites git history. If the commit has been pushed:

  • Force push will be required
  • May affect other collaborators
  • Should be avoided on shared branches (like main)

docs.title: --delete: Delete Existing Commits
docs.text:
Delete commits from history:

ccg --delete

Features:

  • Interactive commit selection
  • Shows full commit details before deletion
  • Uses git reset --hard HEAD~1 for latest commit
  • Uses interactive rebase for older commits
  • Requires explicit confirmation
  • Offers force push for commits already on remote

Workflow:

  1. Choose how many recent commits to display
  2. Select commit by number or hash
  3. View commit details
  4. Confirm deletion (with warnings)
  5. Commit is permanently removed
  6. Optionally force push

Warning: Destructive Operation

Deleting commits is irreversible. Make sure you:

  • Have a backup if needed
  • Understand the impact on commit history
  • Coordinate with team members for shared branches
  • Use force push carefully

docs.title: --tag: Create and Push Tags
docs.text:
Create semantic version tags:

ccg --tag

Features:

  • Validates tag format (Semantic Versioning)
  • Supports annotated tags with messages
  • Checks remote access before pushing
  • Pushes tag to remote automatically

Workflow:

  1. Enter tag name (validated against SemVer)
  2. Choose between annotated or lightweight tag
  3. Enter tag message (for annotated tags)
  4. Confirm push to remote

Semantic Versioning

CCG validates tags against SemVer 2.0.0 specification:

  • MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH
  • Optional pre-release: -alpha, -beta.1
  • Optional build metadata: +20250112

docs.title: --reset: Discard Changes and Pull
docs.text:
Reset local changes and pull latest from remote:

ccg --reset

Features:

  • Discards all uncommitted changes
  • Removes untracked files
  • Pulls latest from remote
  • Requires explicit confirmation

Workflow:

  1. Check for local changes
  2. Show destructive warning
  3. Require user confirmation
  4. Discard changes with git reset HEAD, git checkout ., git clean -fd
  5. Pull latest with git pull

Warning: Data Loss

This operation is destructive and irreversible:

  • All uncommitted changes are lost
  • Untracked files are deleted
  • Cannot be undone

docs.title: --path: Work with Specific Paths
docs.text:
Specify files, directories, or repository paths:

ccg --path <path1> [path2] [...]

Two Modes:

docs.title: Mode 1: Change Working Directory
docs.text:
When providing a single directory, CCG changes to that directory and operates there:

ccg --path /path/to/another/repo

docs.title: Mode 2: Stage Specific Files
docs.text:
When providing multiple paths or files, CCG stages only those paths:

ccg --path src/app.py tests/test_app.py
ccg --path src/ docs/

Combined with Other Flags:

# Edit commit in different repository
ccg --path /path/to/repo --edit

# Push from different repository
ccg --path /path/to/repo --push

# Create tag in specific repository
ccg --path /path/to/repo --tag

Validation:

  • Paths must exist
  • Paths must be within a git repository
  • Invalid paths show helpful error messages

docs.title: --version: Show Version
docs.text:
Display CCG version information:

ccg --version

docs.title: --help: Show Help
docs.text:
Display usage information and available flags:

ccg --help

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text: CCG provides clear error messages for common issues:

docs.title: Not a Git Repository
docs.text:
✗ Not a git repository. Please initialize one with 'git init'.

Solution: Run git init or cd to a git repository.

docs.title: No Remote Configured
docs.text:
✗ No remote repository configured

Solution: Add a remote: git remote add origin <url>

docs.title: No Changes to Commit
docs.text:
✗ No changes to commit in the specified path(s). Make some changes before running the tool.

Solution: Make changes to files, then run CCG.

docs.title: Access Denied
docs.text:
✗ ACCESS DENIED: You don't have permission to access this repository.
✗ Please check:
   You have push access to this repository
   The repository URL is correct
   You're logged in with the correct account

Solution: Check your git credentials and repository permissions.
